abstract: The proposal  backed by Senator Ron Wyden as a replacement to the antipiracy legislation making its way through Congress would look to the International Trade Commission, rather than United States agencies, to curb piracy at foreign Web sites.
snippet: The proposal  backed by Senator Ron Wyden as a replacement to the antipiracy legislation making its way through Congress would look to the International Trade Commission, rather than United States agencies, to curb piracy at foreign Web sites.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Senator Ron Wyden, who has said that he would filibuster the antipiracy Protect I.P. Act because it threatens a free Internet, now has a counterproposal on the table: let the International Trade Commission go after those who sell pirated copyrighted material on the Web from abroad.

headline.main: Opponent of Antipiracy Bill Backs Counterproposal

abstract: Google’s new plan to partner with retailers and start a delivery service is an example of how big tech companies are branching out and blurring the lines between their businesses.
snippet: Google’s new plan to partner with retailers and start a delivery service is an example of how big tech companies are branching out and blurring the lines between their businesses.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In another foray into commerce, Google is working on a delivery service that would let people order items from local stores on the Web and receive them at their homes or offices within a day.

headline.main: A New Google Venture, and Another Web Boundary Line Is Nudged
headline.print_headline: A New Google Venture, and Another Web Boundary Line Is Nudged

byline.original: By Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton

abstract: Why Tom Glocer is out at Thomson Reuters, Google mulls a new local delivery service and David Pogue gets feedback from Barnes & Noble.
snippet: Why Tom Glocer is out at Thomson Reuters, Google mulls a new local delivery service and David Pogue gets feedback from Barnes & Noble.
lead_paragraph: The news and financial services giant Thomson Reuters announced a shakeup in its leadership late Thursday afternoon, Amy Chozick reported, replacing its chief executive, Thomas H. Glocer, after he had struggled to turn around the company in an increasingly competitive market. The Wall Street Journal put those declining fortunes starkly, quoting the projected 2011 breakdown of the $24 billion financial-data market by Burton-Taylor International Consulting: Thomson Reuters at 31.4 percent of the market, down from 37.4 percent in 2005; Bloomberg LP at 30.8 percent of the market, up from 25.1 percent in 2005.

abstract: The Justice Department ended a six-month investigation of Google’s move to buy Admeld, a display advertising company, for $400 million. Regulators approved the deal, saying that they determined that Web publishers rely on many display advertising tools and that there is unlikely to be one dominant company.
snippet: The Justice Department ended a six-month investigation of Google’s move to buy Admeld, a display advertising company, for $400 million. Regulators approved the deal, saying that they determined that Web publishers rely on many display advertising ...
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Friday approved Google’s roughly $400 million acquisition of Admeld, an online display advertising company.

headline.main: Justice Department Approves Google’s Purchase of Admeld
